title: 111_hr5913
content: The "Text a Tip Act of 2010" establishes a pilot program for texting crime tips. The Attorney General can provide grants to law enforcement agencies for implementing an anonymous tip program via cell phone text messaging. The funds can be used for operating expenses, promotion of the program, and the federal share of the grant should not exceed 75 percent of the program cost. The Federal share of a grant under this Act shall not exceed 75 percent of the program cost and grant amounts should supplement, not supplant, non-Federal funds for activities funded under this Act. The program requirements under this Act stipulate that the Federal share of a grant should not exceed 75 percent of the program cost and grant amounts must supplement, not replace, non-Federal funds for activities funded under this Act. A texting tip program of a State or local law enforcement agency eligible for a grant under this Act must comply with certain requirements: the agency must administer the program, incoming text messages must be stripped of identifying information, texts must be untraceable, the program should not replace existing hotlines, personnel must be trained to respond to tips, the program should be compatible with most mobile phone providers, and include unidentifiable features. The texting program for law enforcement agencies should be compatible with most mobile phone providers and include an unidentifiable code for tipsters to send follow-up information. It should also have a feature to abort tips and not impose additional fees on tipsters' mobile phones. Agencies should promote the program to encourage citizen participation, especially among youth. To apply for a grant under this Act, a State or local law enforcement agency must submit an application to the Attorney General with required information. The application must include certifications that the program meets the Act's requirements. Additionally, reports and evaluations are required under this Act. SEC. 5. REPORTS AND EVALUATIONS. Recipients of grants must submit yearly reports on the effectiveness of activities funded by the grant to the Attorney General. The Attorney General will then submit a yearly report to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees on the activities carried out under this Act. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines a "texting tip program" as a program allowing citizens to anonymously text tips to law enforcement agencies to aid in criminal justice. It also authorizes $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2011 to 2016 for the Attorney General to carry out this Act.
